awd_titl_txt: START UP SJV: STEM Teachers Alliance for Regional Tech thinking through Underrepresented Professional development in the San Joaquin Valley
awd_abstract_narration:
The University of California, Merced in collaboration with local school administration officials, teacher preparation program staff, and both in-service and pre-service teachers, will develop a Research Practitioner Partnership focused on High School.  The goal of the project is to create a self-sustaining and scalable professional development program, called START UP SJV, to support high school teachers who teach Computer Science. The START UP SJV program will aim to help teachers improve their own computer programming and computational thinking skills, so that they can better teach their students.

The START UP SJV project will develop an online and supported educational and engagement platform called Compass to leverage existing tools and curriculum from ECS and TEALS, and set up the materials with accompanying exercises on the online Compass educational platform. The Compass system allows participants to read materials, work on code, and get support all in one place. To provide real-time support on the system, the PIs will recruit advanced Computer Science Engineering undergraduate students from UC Merced, a Hispanic-serving institution, who will sign up for course credit, and serve as support personnel on the system, answering participant's questions and providing overall guidance and support.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: Computer Science for All (CS for All)

por.por_cntn:
The START UP SJV project was an effort create a community of educators, administrators, and researchers in the heart of California's Central Valley, aimed at increasing participation in Computing for the local population. Hosted and administered at the University of California, Merced (UC Merced), educators and administrators from Merced Union High School District (MUHSD), and MercedCounty Office of Education (MCOE) participated in the project throughout its various stages.

There were a total of 8 high school teachers, from 7 different schools,  who participated in Summer Bootcamp workshops, conducted by researchers at UCMerced. The aim of these week-long workshops was to get teachers from different schools together, discuss the challenges they face in delivering their AP Computer Science courses, and collaboratively come up with solutions that would work for everyone.

The first challenge identified in the group was that the teachers had a different degree of familiarity with the AP Computer Science A material, and the Java programming language. To address this, we designed Professional Development materials that all participants went through, in an effort to improve their own programming and computational thinking skills.

Another challenge for the project was the lack of uniformity across the different schools with respect to curriculum, and IT infrastructure. Every participating teacher was using different course materials, from various providers, and none of them had the ability to install software development tools on student computers. In most cases students were provided with Chromebooks, making it difficult to install compilers, while others had lab spaces with PCs for the students to use, but lacked the adequate support from their IT departments. To address this challenge, we hosted an online IDE with the Java compiler preinstalled, and made it accessible to students through their web browser. This alleviated the technical difficulties, allowing students to compile and run the code they were writing.

We anticipated that teachers would need additional support in their classrooms, so we setup an upper-division course at UC Merced, with 5 advancedundergraduate students, who served as learning assistants for the high school students. Since we had an online IDE, the learning assistants could login to a student's workspace in the cloud and communicate with the student via text or video chat, offering help on their programming exercises.

The final challenge was related to administrative support for AP Computer Science A in our district. We discovered that teachers who offered AP Computer Science A were not given separate sections to teach these classes, instead having the AP Computer Science students sit in their regular class that they were teaching, and work quietly on their own. 

The reason for this was that there were not enough students interested in AP Computer Science A, so the school administrators could not justify opening a section for them. Indeed, each school had no more than 3-4 students taking AP Computer Science A, while some schools had none.

The rest of the time in the project was spent attempting to determine the reason why there are so few students interested in taking AP Computer Science A in high school. The primary reason identified by the teachers involved in the program was the financial cost associated with taking AP exams. All 8 teachers were unanimous on this, indicating that cost of taking an AP exam is prohibitively expensive for many families in our district. Upon further investigation, we found that the district sponsors up to two AP exams for every students, but counselorsare advising students to take other AP classes, such as English and Calculus, which students are told would be more useful in college, as they satisfy Math and Writing requirements. 

In an interview with a senior local administrator, we were told that instead of AP Computer Science A, a lot of students are opting to take Introduction to Programming courses at their local Community Colleges. It is the opinion of this administrator that AP Computer Science A enrollments will continue to decline in our district, and that our efforts would be best suited elsewhere.

As an unintended positive outcome, a Graduate Student Researcher (GSR) who was supported by the project became interested in pursuing a full-time career in Computer Science Education, and is currently applying for Teaching Faculty positions in the San Joaquin Valley. This particular GSR grew up in the area, is a member of an underrepresented minority group, and is a DACA recipient. In our quest to broaden participation for underrepresented groups in the Central Valley of California, we have raised a future faculty member from an underrepresented group, who will undoubtedly do much for Computer Science Education in our area.


Last Modified: 04/15/2024
Modified by: Angelo Kyrilov
